STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
August 7, 2023
Maureen Therese Clore
ANTRIM/CHARLEVOIX/EMMET COUNTY DHHS
2229 SUMMIT PARK DR,
PETOSKEY, MI, 49770-8636
Re: License #: CP240201034
Dear Maureen Therese Clore:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
July 25, 2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Linda Tansil, Area Manager, at 248-860-0787.
Sincerely,
Doug Turrill Licensing Consultant
enclosure
2

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans/PATP
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain
signatures from the following individuals, as applicable:
Caseworker. • Supervisor. • Second line supervisor, when
siblings in care are placed apart. • Parents who are a
member of a participating household. • Youth ages 14 and
older. • Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated
court ordered caregivers.
Three files and twelve treatment plans were reviewed. Five of twelve treatment plans
documented late signatures.
File 1. One USP dated June 12, 2023, was signed by the relative on July 17, 2023.
A second USP dated March 14, 2023, was signed on April 14, 2023. A third USP
dated December 14, 2023, was signed on January 24, 2023.
File 2. A USP dated September 6, 2022, was signed by the parent on October 19,
2022, and by the second parent on November 10, 2022.
File 3. A USP dated September 28, 2022, was signed by the parent on June 20,
2023. A second USP dated March 27, 2023, was signed by the parent on May 12,
2023.
Repeat Violation:
07/25/2022 Renewal Inspection – CAP approved August 18, 2022.
2

FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables: Updated Case Plan (USP) -
within 30 calendar days before the case plan due date.
Three files and 12 FTM’s were reviewed. One of twelve FTM’s occurred after the
USP due date. The USP was due March 14, 2023 and the FTM was completed on
March 24, 2023.
Repeat Violation:
07/25/2022 Renewal Inspection – CAP approved August 18, 2022.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
• Technical assistance was not offered at this time.
V. CONSULTATION
• Consultation was not offered or requested at this time.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has not been required to submit any corrective action plans during
this period under review.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrators report was thorough and well written. The report detailed
the agency efforts to address rule and policy non-compliances established during
licensing inspections and the agency's internal quality reviews.
Financial Overview
The agency is a local DHHS office and financial records were not available.
Staff and Youth Interviews
3

Staff interviewed report feeling very supported by their supervisors and also feel
their supervisors are competent and knowledgeable. Staff also reported that they
are part of a supportive and high functioning team.
Youth were not interviewed by the consultant.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency is a local DHHS office and is spacious and well maintained.
VII. CPA ANALYST FINDINGS
The CPA Analyst initiated three safety alerts during her visits tom the homes. They
are as follows:
Safety Alert 1. A safety alert was generated and sent to the agency on May 15,
2023. The agency provided the home with trigger locks and photos of the installed
locks were provided. Resolution obtained on May 19, 2023.
Safety Alert 2. A safety alert was generated on May 18, 2023, as the kitchen ceiling
in the home was unfinished due to a pipe leaking. The agency was aware of the
problem and was assisting the family in obtaining FIG funding. The agency
submitted a variance on May 19, 2023.
Safety Alert 3. A safety alert was generated on May 18, 2023, as the home was
lacking a carbon monoxide detector and a cabinet with cleaning supplies was
withing reach of children. The carbon monoxide detector and locks on the cabinets
were installed on May 19, 2023. Photos were provided. Safety alert resolved.
During the audit entrance meeting the CPA Analyst reported that foster parents and
relatives feel supported by the agency and are satisfied with services.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
August 7, 2023
________________________________________
Douglas W Turrill Date
Licensing Consultant
